title: How to Remove Blood from Satin Sheets

steps.headline: Check the care tags of your satin sheets.
steps.description: These will usually indicate the material that the satin sheets are made of, and whether they are washable or for dry-cleaning only. Proceed with this cleaning method after you have verified that the material is safe for washing. Material such as polyester or nylon can usually be washed gently, while acetate or silk is more suitable for dry-cleaning.

steps.headline: If the stain is still fresh, blot out as much of the blood as possible with clean paper towels.
Add about 4 tablespoons of table salt to a gallon of cold water in a bucket.
steps.description: Swish the water around to allow the salt to dissolve.

steps.headline: Soak the stained satin sheets in the salt water solution.
steps.description: Depending on how long the stain has been on the satin material, allow the sheets to soak for an hour or longer, until the stain starts to fade. The salt breaks down the proteins in blood, allowing for more effective removal from the satin sheets.

steps.headline: Gently wash the satin sheets in cold water and a bleach-free laundry detergent safe for delicates.
steps.description: You can either hand-wash or use a washing machine at the gentlest cycle.

steps.headline: Check the material if the stain has been fully removed.
steps.description: If there are still traces of the stain, soak the satin sheets in a mixture of cold water and bleach-free laundry detergent for about 30 minutes to an hour. Rinse the sheets with cold water once the stain has been completely removed.

methods.name: Removing Stains from Dry Clean Only Fabric

steps.headline: Check the care tags of your satin sheets.
steps.description: These will usually indicate the material that the satin sheets are made of, and whether they are washable or for dry-cleaning only. Proceed with this cleaning method if the material is for dry-cleaning only.

steps.headline: Dab on the stain with a sponge or washcloth soaked in cold water, and try to remove as much of the stain as you can.
Sprinkle some salt on the remainder of the stain.
Take your satin sheets to your dry cleaner as soon as possible, and allow them to take care of removing the rest of the stain.

text: Removing Stains From Washable Fabric Check the care tags of your satin sheets. These will usually indicate the material that the satin sheets are made of, and whether they are washable or for dry-cleaning only. Proceed with this cleaning method after you have verified that the material is safe for washing. Material such as polyester or nylon can usually be washed gently, while acetate or silk is more suitable for dry-cleaning. If the stain is still fresh, blot out as much of the blood as possible with clean paper towels.  Add about 4 tablespoons of table salt to a gallon of cold water in a bucket. Swish the water around to allow the salt to dissolve. Soak the stained satin sheets in the salt water solution. Depending on how long the stain has been on the satin material, allow the sheets to soak for an hour or longer, until the stain starts to fade. The salt breaks down the proteins in blood, allowing for more effective removal from the satin sheets. Gently wash the satin sheets in cold water and a bleach-free laundry detergent safe for delicates. You can either hand-wash or use a washing machine at the gentlest cycle. Check the material if the stain has been fully removed. If there are still traces of the stain, soak the satin sheets in a mixture of cold water and bleach-free laundry detergent for about 30 minutes to an hour.
